history.content:
If you're going down the AI/ML side (classes like 100/188/189/126/127), the concepts you need to know from Math 53 mostly involve vector calculus operations (partial derivatives, gradients, hessians, jacobians, double/triple integrals). For what it's worth, I didn't take Math 53 at Berkeley and in my experience with some of these classes (I've taken 100/188/127 so far), I've never felt at a disadvantage in terms of calculus preparation. 

As a side note, Math 53 can also be petitioned to count as a CS technical Upper Div course, so it can still help to take it if you want extra math preparation. 

----------

Not necessary. I didn't take 53, and did well in 134 and 189. Just self-study partial derivative & multiple integral.

If you're going down the AI/ML side (classes like 100/188/189/126/127), the concepts you need to know from Math 53 mostly involve vector calculus operations (partial derivatives, gradients, hessians, jacobians, double/triple integrals). For what it's worth, I didn't take Math 53 at Berkeley and in my experience with some of these classes (I've taken 100/188/127 so far), I've never felt at a disadvantage in terms of calculus preparation. 

As a side note, Math 53 can also be petitioned to count as a CS technical Upper Div course, so it can still help to take it if you want extra math preparation.

children.subject: Basically, there's not really a need to do 53?
Not from the perspective of preparing for Shewchuk's 189, at least in my experience

Teach yourself partial derivatives and chain rule (which you cover in 53), and vector calculus (which you see only a bit of in 53). I'd recommend learning vector calculus from EECS 127; they had a lecture and a discussion devoted to it this past semester

I was in a similar boat deciding whether or not to take it, and I've decided to just not take it and self study the book, specifically chapters 14 (partial derivatives) and 15 (multiple integrals). I've heard the other parts of 53 are less applicable.

history.content:
I am a CS major in L&S. MATH 53 in not a requirement but I have heard some people say that it's really useful for upper div CS courses. Is that true? If yes, which courses? Also, are there only some parts which can be self studied or is the entire content important and it is recommended that one takes the course?

Thanks!
history.subject: Worth Doing Math 53 for 189 and other CS upper divs?
